# Course Information Hub

Welcome to the central hub for course organization in **BIOL 497/597 â€“ Genomics & Bioinformatics**. This webpage consolidates all essential information related to **assignment deadlines**, the **weekly schedule**, and the **typical structure of class meetings**.  

Here you will find:

# Schedule {#schedule}

The tentative schedule for this course is provided in Table \@ref(tab:timetab). Please note that the instructor may adjust our schedule to accommodate the courseâ€™s progress and studentsâ€™ needs. Any changes will be communicated to enrolled students in a timely manner.

```{r timetab, echo=FALSE}
###~~~
# Build a data frame with all dates from beginning to end of Fall semester
###~~~
dates <- data.frame(seq.Date(from=as.Date("2026/01/12"), to=as.Date("2026/05/01"), by="day"))
#Assign a name to the col (allows using $)
colnames(dates) <- "Date"

###~~~
# Find weekdays associated to dates
###~~~
#Add a col to dataframe with weekday
dates$Weekday <- weekdays(dates$Date)

###~~~
# Classes only take place on Wed and Fri. So, extract dates matching class weekdays
###~~~
#Subset dates based on selected weekdays
datesclass <- subset(dates, dates$Weekday %in% c("Wednesday"))

###~~~
# Add week ID (from 1 to 16) to object from step 4
###~~~
#Create weekID vector and add it in front of dataframe
datesclass <- data.frame(WeekID = sort(rep(seq(from=1, to=16, by=1), 1)), datesclass)

###~~~
# Exclude dates falling during holiday break
###~~~
#Establish vector of dates related to holidays
holiday <- seq.Date(from=as.Date("2026/03/16"), to=as.Date("2026/03/20"), by="day")

#Find and exclude holidays
datesclass <- datesclass[-which(datesclass$Date %in% holiday),]

###~~~
#Read in csv with topics and tasks
###~~~
topic <- read.csv("Data/topics_classes_2026.csv") 
topic <- as.data.frame(topic)

###~~~
#Produce final timetable
###~~~
timetable <- data.frame(datesclass, topic)

###~~~
#Plot timetable in doc
###~~~
knitr::kable(timetable,  caption = "Tentative schedule for Genomics and Bioinformatics, Spring 2026 semester.", format = "html", row.names = FALSE) %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed"))
#PDF

#                       %>% kable_styling(latex_options = c("striped","scale_down"))
#)
```

# Class Structure {#classstr}

The weekly class structure is summarized in Table \@ref(tab:classstr).

A typical class meeting is structured as follows:

- An initial **lecture component** (ca. 50 minutes) introducing key concepts and methods  
- A brief **break and transition period**  
- A **laboratory session** (ca. 1 hour 40 minutes), which may include group activities, guided exercises, or computer-based data analysis 

During the **first several weeks of the semester**, class time will emphasize lectures and structured group activities to build foundational knowledge and skills. As the semester progresses, the course will gradually transition to **primarily computer-based laboratory work**, with increased emphasis on independent and applied problem-solving.

```{r classstr, echo=FALSE, warning = F, message = F}
###~~~
# Read in csv with weekly class structure, prevent R from changing names
class <- read.csv("Data/Class_structure.csv", check.names = FALSE) 
class <- as.data.frame(class)

###~~~
# Update column names for columns 2 to 4 to display times nicely
colnames(class)[2:4] <- c("9:00â€“9:50 a.m.", "9:50â€“10:05 a.m.", "10:05â€“11:45 a.m.")

###~~~
# Plot timetable in document
knitr::kable(class, 
             caption = "Weekly class structure for Genomics and Bioinformatics, Spring 2026 semester.", 
             format = "html", 
             row.names = FALSE) %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed"))
```
